title: 114_hr2076
content: The "Marijuana Businesses Access to Banking Act of 2015" may be cited as the short title. It provides a safe harbor for depository institutions. A Federal banking regulator may not terminate or limit deposit insurance for providing financial services to marijuana-related businesses, prohibit or penalize institutions for serving these businesses, or discourage offering financial services to individuals based solely on marijuana-related activities. Federal banking regulators are prohibited from taking adverse actions against financial institutions offering services to marijuana-related businesses or individuals involved in such businesses. This includes not penalizing institutions for serving these businesses or discouraging services based solely on marijuana-related activities. Federal banking regulators cannot penalize financial institutions for providing services to marijuana-related legitimate businesses or individuals involved in such businesses, including leasing real estate or equipment to these businesses. Federal banking regulators are prohibited from penalizing financial institutions for offering services to marijuana-related legitimate businesses or individuals involved in such businesses, such as leasing real estate or equipment. In states where marijuana is legal, financial institutions providing services to marijuana-related businesses are protected from federal liability for complying with state laws. Financial institutions providing services to marijuana-related businesses, or to owners of real estate or equipment leased to such businesses, are protected from federal forfeiture under any law for providing loans. The Act does not mandate depository institutions to offer financial services to marijuana-related legitimate businesses. Additionally, there are requirements for filing suspicious activity reports. Section 5318(g) of title 31, United States Code is amended to include requirements for marijuana-related businesses to comply with guidance issued by the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network regarding suspicious transaction reports. The amendment to Section 5318(g) of title 31, United States Code ensures that reports of suspicious transactions do not hinder financial services for marijuana-related legitimate businesses in states where marijuana is legal. The term 'marijuana-related legitimate business' is defined in the Marijuana Businesses Access to Banking Act of 2015. The term 'marijuana-related legitimate business' is defined in the Marijuana Businesses Access to Banking Act of 2015. In this Act, "depository institution" refers to banks, credit unions, and other financial institutions. "Federal banking regulator" includes various government agencies overseeing banking activities. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of terms related to financial services and marijuana-related businesses. Financial service is defined as a product or service related to banking or financial services. A manufacturer is defined as a person involved in the production or packaging of marijuana products. A marijuana-related legitimate business includes manufacturers and producers involved in handling marijuana products. The curr_chunk defines terms related to marijuana businesses, including activities like cultivating, producing, selling, and distributing marijuana products. It also defines terms like "marijuana" and "marijuana product" as per the Controlled Substances Act. The curr_chunk defines the term "State" as each of the several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and any territory or possession of the United States.
